title: I'm trying to fill out divorce forms on my own and I have no idea what to put on form FL-141. I'm the petitioner.
question: Help?
answers:
The answers from both of my colleagues are correct. It may be instructive to understand that California law requires Declarations of full financial disclosure to be served by each party on the other.

The law specifically requires (Family Code § 2103) “... each party to a proceeding for dissolution of the marriage or legal separation of the parties shall serve on the other party a preliminary declaration of disclosure ...” (“shall” means must)

Each party must first serve a “Preliminary declaration of disclosure” and “... the parties shall file proof of service of the preliminary declaration of disclosure with the court.” (The proof of service is a form that explains in detail specifically how the document(s) were served (delivered according to the rules) on the other party.)

The law also requires a “Final declaration of disclosure”, (there is a way to agree to waive that requirement, but the parties must comply with the requirements outlined in the Family Code Sections 2102, 2104 et. sec.)

Once the foregoing is complete, the parties must file Form No.FL-141 “Declaration Regarding Service of Declaration of Disclosure” which basically confirms to the court that you have satisfied ALL the procedural requirements. Therefore, after you have served the financial documents on your spouse including the Income & Expense Declaration, Property Declaration and/or Schedule of Assets and Debts, filed your proof of service for both the Preliminary and Final Declaration of Disclosure, you complete FL-141.

Still confused? If you are doing it yourself, contact either the "Self Help" center or the Facilitator at your courthouse. Or contact an experienced family law attorney.

Good luck.

Disclaimer: I am licensed to practice law in the state of California. Therefore if your case in not in California, the information contained herein may not apply. This answer is provided as a public service and as a general response to a general question, it is not meant, and should not be relied upon as specific legal advice, nor does it create an attorney-client relationship .

This form asks you to describe how you served your Income and Expense Declaration on your soon to be ex-spouse. Did you mail it or have it served personally ? You only have to fill out 1 and 2 as it sounds like this is not your Final Declaration of Disclosure. For 1, check Petitioner. For 2, on the first line check Petitioner. On the second line, check Respondent and then check personal service or mail. You can also look at the self-help weblink below.

The response given is not intended to create, nor does it create an ongoing duty to respond to questions. The response does not form an attorney-client relationship, nor is it intended to be anything other than the educated opinion of the author. It should not be relied upon as legal advice. The response given is based upon the limited facts provided by the person asking the question. To the extent additional or different facts exist, the response might possibly change. Attorney is licensed to practice law only in the State of California. Responses are based solely on California law unless stated otherwise.
This is one of the reasons people hire attorneys. Or you can go to the courthouse and talk to the Family Law Facilitator.
